citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Approximately 2 weeks ago, the licensee explained attempting to hand rear a few days old joey that was rejected by his
mother. Per the licensee, the joey was lethargic, having difficulty nursing, overall failing to thrive, and died after 3 days of
hand feeding. The licensee followed the pre-established veterinarian’s guidance on hand rearing but did not consult with
the veterinarian when the joey’s condition did not improve. In failing to consult with the veterinarian once initial care was
unsuccessful, the licensee did not obtain updated treatment guidelines that may have helped the animal’s condition or
reduced his pain/discomfort. In coordination with the attending veterinarian, the licensee must develop a thorough hand
rearing plan including a clear description of when to contact the veterinarian for further treatments. To be corrected by
10/27/2023.

The facility did not adequately document animal deaths as part of the disposition information. Joeys’ deaths were not
documented and, per the licensee, some of the deaths that were documented were confusing or inaccurate. The
document also did not contain the date of death. Adequate record keeping is required to help reflect medical issues and
trends at the facility. Develop and maintain records disclosing the required disposition information including the date of all
animal disposals including animal deaths.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 12/18/2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Critical
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Approximately 2 weeks ago, the licensee explained attempting to hand rear a few days old joey that was rejected by his 
mother. Per the licensee, the joey was lethargic, having difficulty nursing, overall failing to thrive, and died after 3 days of 
hand feeding. The licensee followed the pre-established veterinarian’s guidance on hand rearing but did not consult with 
the veterinarian when the joey’s condition did not improve. In failing to consult with the veterinarian once initial care was 
unsuccessful, the licensee did not obtain updated treatment guidelines that may have helped the animal’s condition or 
reduced his pain/discomfort. In coordination with the attending veterinarian, the licensee must develop a thorough hand 
rearing plan including a clear description of when to contact the veterinarian for further treatments. To be corrected by 
10/27/2023. 
2.75(b)(1)(v) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility did not adequately document animal deaths as part of the disposition information. Joeys’ deaths were not 
documented and, per the licensee, some of the deaths that were documented were confusing or inaccurate. The 
document also did not contain the date of death. Adequate record keeping is required to help reflect medical issues and 
trends at the facility. Develop and maintain records disclosing the required disposition information including the date of all 
animal disposals including animal deaths. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 12/18/2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and 
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.

n
